data.title: Copy-paste doesn't work properly with Unix-style line endings under Windows
data.body:
Copying (Ctrl+C-Ctrl+V) from a file with Unix-style line ending (LF) doesn't work as expected, since line endings are _preserved_ on the clipboard.

This causes a wide range of issues:
- you can't paste text in an application that doesn't handle LF (notepad for example, but if you're using vim over PuTTY that also doesn't work)
- even if the other app handles LF, you have to be consistent, so you can't paste text from an CRLF file into a LF one or vice versa

This issue is briefly discussed in #2822, and it is the reason of #5808.

**All other editors convert line endings in text placed on the clipboard** (Sublime Text, jEdit, etc.), so in this regard Atom behaves rather strangely compared to other editors.

The proposed solution in #2822 (configurable line endings) is insufficient since it's based on the assumption that _all_ files edited by the user are using the same line ending.
For example, if I've got a file with LF line endings and I'd like to use copy-paste, then I **have to convert it to CRLF** and then **copy the text** I want, and **then convert it back to LF** to preserve the original format. I wouldn't call editing LF files on Windows a rare use case, especially among Atom's users.

Atom should convert any text's line ending to the platform's native line ending _before_ it is placed on the clipboard. This conversion should only be done on the content that is placed on the clipboard—the text in the buffer should not be changed.

data.title: Better detection of git repository inside a symlink dir
data.body:
I tend to have symbolic links to some of my subdirectories in a large repository. When I open atom from the symlink directory it does not detect that the file is part of a project. As a result, packages such as `git-plus` also do not detect that I am actually inside a git repository.

Git provides the command `git rev-parse --show-toplevel` which I think is a more robust way of detecting a git repository than traversing the tree to find the `.git` folder. There is also `git rev-parse --git-dir` to find the path to the `.git` directory if this is needed. Most things `git` I know (bash terminal with git status line and `vim-fugitive` simply detect I'm in a repository irrespective if there is a `.git` subdirectory in the parents of the directory I'm in) and I think it will be a really neat feature if `atom` detected the fact that the files it's editing are being tracked by git no matter where it finds them.

I should mention I'm on a linux (arch linux) using atom version 1.0.3.

I would submit a pull request but I'm not very good with coffee script and I'm afraid it might affect many parts of atom which I'm not aware of.

data.title: Support `editor.tabType`
data.body:
This does the simplest thing possible. When `editor.tabType` is set to `auto`, it does what it did before. When it is set to `hard` or `soft`, it uses those values all the time unless `setSoftTabs()` is explicitly called. The API is unchanged. Specs have been consolidated a bit as there were a couple places where the tab stuff was being tested.

Eventually (another PR), I'd like to change the name of `editor.softTabs` setting to `editor.defaultTabType` or something more clear. 

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8186 @Abdillah, I've used a couple of your commits.
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3719

data.title: Windows 10 - Crashes
data.body:
## Apologies in advance

I apologize if this has already been reported, but I couldn't find it anywhere.  Please close this issue if that's the case.  It's an oddball case.
## Platform and Version

**Platform** Windows 10
**Version** Atom 1.0.7
**Safe Mode?** Yep, that crashes too.
**Remote FileSystem** SMB Share from Mac machine (Yosemite) (as a mapped drive or as just the share itself).
## Steps to Reproduce
- Create a samba (SMB) share on a Mac machine.
- Navigate to that share on your Windows machine and authenticate.
- Tell Atom.io to open a directory within that share.
- With Windows Explorer, change a file name within the share, or simply re-navigate to the share by going to a directory above the one you opened with Atom.io and then back into the opened directory.  There are many, many things you can do at this point.
- Atom.io crashes.
## Other Tests

My situation might be a bit _unique_ so again I will apologize if it makes it hard to debug. I have tested this same setup using a linux samba share as well as a Windows file share and Atom.io behaves very well and **_never crashes**_ in those setups.  It might be something to do with how the Mac (Yosemite) samba shares are created.

All shares I used required authentication different from that of my Windows workstation.  All shares were on an AD domain using domain credentials.

data.title: Buffer.byteLength is returning a wrong value sometimes
data.body:
This is kinda a bizarre error. If I have a string with accents, and try to use `Buffer.byteLength`, it returns the same as `string.length`. But only in certains conditions.

The only way I found out on how to always reproduce this error is paste, line by line, the code below in the console. It gives us an error for the global variable json:

``` javascript
var data = {"id":4,"name":"Critério de Aceitação","value":""};

// If i just copy-paste all these lines, the results are correct.
// But, if I paste one by one these lines in the console, they give the following cases:
json = JSON.stringify(data);
console.log(Buffer.byteLength(json)); // 50
console.log(Buffer.byteLength(JSON.stringify(data))); // 53
```

But I found the problem while working on a plugin that try to POST a JSON to a HTTPS Redmine service. It was a CoffeeScript plugin, so there's no possible way to create global variables. It was really strange when I logged into console and saw different results for different ways of calling this method. Somehow, I wasn't able to reproduce this error on IO.js nor in Node.JS alone.

In my plugin, I found this bug in the following lines:

``` coffee
  # data is a { issue: { project_id: 99, title: "Sóme códe" }} - like object
    result = ''
    apiKey = atom.config.get('plugin.redmine_api_key')
    json = JSON.stringify(data)
    size = Buffer.byteLength(json)
    size < Buffer.byteLength(JSON.stringify(data)) # This returned TRUE!
```

But when I tried to create a simple package trying to reproduce this error, this did not happened.

What I did to correct this on my package was add `json = ''` before the line that stringifies my JS object. To help more in debugging this (really!) strange problem, the `title` field (the one that is possible to come with accents) was typed by a user, using a `TextEditorView`.

Atom version: 1.0.4
OS: Ubuntu Linux  14.04

data.title: Windows scripts not updated after updating
data.body:
`C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\atom\bin` doesn't seem to be updated after an update has been installed. Though atom added this directory to the PATH variable so atom is available from the windows console.

So then there is a update and this is showing up in the console:

```
> atom .
The system cannot find the path specified.
```

So it happens that atom updated to version 1.0.6, but when I look at the files in `C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\atom\bin` I can see that these ~~binary~~ executable files all refer to `app-1.0.4`. By having this issue multiple times, I know I can fix this by rewriting this to `app-1.0.6`, but it would be very convenient if the updater all does this on instead of wasting time on figuring out why its not working.

data.title: Find in Project initially returns no results in 1.0.6
data.body:
After updating to 1.0.6, I noticed that Find in Project initially returns no results for a search that I expect to return many results. After waiting several minutes and executing the search again, I finally see the results I expect.

If it is indexing or something behind the scenes, then I think the user should be informed that is what is happening and not simply told that the search returned no results.

Or in some cases it will pop up the results from a prior search that did return results. e.g. I search for "component" but I'm presented with the results of a prior search for "immutable".
